segments.text: Our next guest is former Special Envoy to the Middle East under President Trump in his
new book, Jason Greenblatt takes readers inside the White House for some of the Trump administration's
biggest diplomacy triumphs, including the signing of the Abraham Accords, author of
the Path of Abraham, how Donald Trump made peace in the Middle East, and how to stop Joe Biden
from unmaking it, Jason Greenblatt joins us now. Welcome to Rising.
Pleasure to be here. Thanks for having me.
Yeah, we're so happy to have you talk to us about the book and how important it was,
you know, from your perspective for this agreement, the Abraham agreement, to be reached.
Well, the book was intended to sort of shatter the myths about the Israeli-Palestinian conflict
and try to give the Biden administration some advice, in particular about the Iran deal,
which they don't seem to be heating if news reports are accurate. So I think it's a particularly
timely book right now, and it does take people into the behind the scenes without any kind
of gossip or backstabbing, but the road that led to the Abraham Accords, which is only
continuing to help stabilize the Middle East.
And what do you think Biden is doing wrong right now? The kind of subtitle of the book
suggests that the Biden administration is threatening or putting in jeopardy what the
Trump administration achieved. Can you tell us more about that?
Yeah, I mean, he's basically making well of our allies once again, as they did with the
Obama administration, very, very uncomfortable, very nervous. They're now trying to figure
out how to ally themselves with others, including China, and even Iran, you see ambassadors
being given again back to Iran and from Iran to the region. So the region is extraordinarily
nervous right now. Nobody knows what to expect when people believe that the Biden administration
is abandoning the region by signing the deal with Iran, or potentially signing the deal
with Iran.
Jason, when I remember hearing about the Abraham Accords, it was very bittersweet on the one
hand. It seemed like such an incredible achievement. On the other hand, talking to dear friends,
Palestinians living in the West Bank, living in Gaza, it was there was something about
it that signaled that they were now no longer sort of on the table in the same way as a barrier
to peace between Israel and these other countries. Talk to me about that from your point of
view. I know that you too have done a lot of advocacy and a lot of diplomacy in those
communities as well. Talk to me about what you would say to Palestinians looking at the
Abraham Accords as something that sort of puts them on the back burner.
Well, I wish they weren't on the back burner. They should be on the front burner. What the
Abraham Accords did was remove a veto card. The Palestinian leadership, and let's remember
this too, is leadership in Ramallah and they are terrorist leaders in Gaza. They are
not willing to negotiate in any way, shape, or form in good faith in a realistic manner
with Israel. So they took themselves off the table, if you will. And I wish that weren't
the case. But what the Abraham Accords did do was prevent them from allowing Israel to
make peace with its Arab neighbors. They did make peace twice before. Now they make peace
several more times. But the people who could gain the most from the Abraham Accords are
actually the Palestinians if they'd only come to the table in good faith.
We pulled out of the Iran deal. I would argue that itself being a destabilizing move that
makes some kind of conflict more likely. And we did that, not Iran, the Biden administration
trying to get back to some kind of understanding with Iran. Do you disagree with that perspective?
Why should we have gotten out of the Iran deal? What was the reason for doing so?
Sure, I do disagree with the perspective. Because what the original Iran deal did was
give Iran a fortune of money, which they then used rather than help their people to
foment terrorism, to throw missiles and rockets at the UAE, at Saudi Arabia, Israel, all sorts
of mischief and bad acts and murder-aschings. In terms of the nuclear part of it, which
of course is the most existential threat to the region, and even potentially to the United
States, it didn't stop Iran from developing nuclear weapons. It simply held off for a
creative time. Once that deal expired, Iran was actually free to develop nuclear weapons.
So the new deal apparently will do the same. Many argue that it's even weaker and shorter.
I don't know because none of us really know what's in there. But what it does is it puts
our head in the sand, pretends the problem isn't there, and hope for the best. And then
we have to tell our kids when there is a problem, well, we did our best to delay things, but
now it's your problem.
But didn't pulling out of the deal, there's no delaying that they can go back to. Because
we did that. If the concern is they might in the future be able to or decide to develop
nuclear weapons anyway, I mean, we took that out of the future and we just made it potentially
now.
Well, what we do need is a plan B. Nobody seems to have come up with a plan B. It's a fair
point. But signing up for a deal that makes no sense is not an excuse for taking a United
Stand against a regime that wants to murder people around it, destroy Israel, take over
Saturn, maybe the UAE and others. So you're right, it's not a perfect situation. But at
the same time, we don't have unity of opinion on this. And that makes it harder to put pressure
on the Iranian regime.
Do you see the Abraham Accords as a cause or a symptom of this kind of realignment that
we're now seeing in the Middle East? And where do you see America's role in that going forward?
I see it as both a cause and a symptom. And I think America can play a tremendous role
if it stood by our allies, if it didn't disrespect Saudi Arabia, although I think President Biden
has started to turn the corner on that. I hope he continues to turn in a big way. But
I think America could play a very strong role encouraging our friends and allies to work
together against terrorism, against the Iranian regime. At the same time, I think that the
region could actually join together even without American leadership. I don't think
that they need America now that the train has left the station in terms of the Iran
deal.
Sorry.
Isn't Saudi Arabia a sponsor of terrorism and violence and all sorts of things just
as like Iran is? So I find it interesting that you say we should have a kind of more
confrontational relationship with Iran, but not with Saudi Arabia. It seems like both
are up to no good in a lot of ways.
Well, Saudi Arabia is not threatening any of its neighbors. Saudi Arabia is not a terror
sponsor state. Saudi Arabia is actually making tremendous strides. I mean, we could talk
about the past or we could talk about the future. The future of Saudi Arabia, I think,
is extraordinarily bright.
You know, President Trump very, very well, you've worked with him for 23 years, I believe,
is the number. You know, in so many ways, he sort of took an axe to the status quo, to
the kind of understanding, you know, of the expert class about so many foreign policy
issues. Where did that come from? Where did his view of what was possible in terms of
foreign relations come from?
So he took a view. I mean, a business like you. If we can make progress, we're going
to make progress. So we can't make progress. We're not going to waste time simply speaking
diplomatic speak. And that's the view and the approach that we took. We were respectful.
We were diplomatic. But we were also pragmatic. And we said, whether it was to the Palestinians
or Israel or Arab neighbors, Israel's Arab neighbors and our allies, look, we're here
to make progress. Either you're going to help us make progress. So we have lots of other
things to do around the world. And we're going to move on to the other things to do. So help
us make progress or not. It's your choice. That's the approach of Trump. He's a very
pragmatic business person. He knows he had a limited amount of time in the White House,
whether it was four years or eight years. And he wanted to make progress.
So on the topic of President Trump, I wonder if we can ask you, we're sort of a few days
out from the affidavit, the heavily redacted affidavit that justified the raid on Mar-a-Lago
being released. I wonder if you can tell us anything, if you're comfortable telling us
anything about Trump's character that would shed light on, you know, how big of a security
risk this pose, what the likelihood is that he took things that would have endangered
America's security home with him tomorrow. Logo, is there any light you can shed on this
from your experience knowing him so well? Sure. So we still don't know a lot of facts. It was
heavily redacted, as you say. The Donald Trump that I know that I worked for for 23 years is a smart
guy. I don't think he would have taken anything that would have endangered people, at least not
knowingly. So I'm still sitting back trying to see, you know, I'm reading everything,
trying to understand what we're talking about. But until we get more facts, I really don't know,
and it's hard to take any kind of opinion. But no, I don't think he would have taken anything
intentionally that would have, I guess, the two accusations are that would have harmed
Americans or spies or informants across the world. And some are even accusing him of taking it
in order to enrich himself to those sound, not like the Donald Trump that I know.
I want to push back one more time on the Saudi Arabia thing, just because I think it's an
important difference between our perspective. You know, there's the Jamal Khashoggi, there's the
airstrikes in Yemen, it killed thousands of people, alleged to be noncombatant civilian
targets, hospitals, etc. I mean, that looks to me like a relationship with a country that is
involved in a lot of violence and a lot of bad stuff. So again, I don't know why it's, it should be,
it seems hypocritical to be like letting them off the hook as Biden now is doing,
he's, you know, wants to beg Saudi Arabia for the oil, I guess we're not producing here.
But to excuse what Saudi Arabia is doing and then to be, but I draw a hard line against Iran,
again, doesn't make a lot of sense from where I'm sitting.
Yeah, well, I agree with your characterization that he's begging Saudi Arabia for the oil that
maybe I would say should be producing here. But the two examples, you know, Yemen,
Yemen, the Houthi rebels were really their terrorists have been attacking Saudi Arabia.
So, Saudi Arabia is defending itself, it's defending its citizens.
It's the obligation of any country to defend itself and its citizens.
No different than when Hamas terrorizes Israel. As far as Jamal Khashoggi, you know, it's hot.
Yes, he took responsibility for what was a heinous act. It was a really just absolutely horrific act.
We don't know with certainty. We know what the CIA says that there's a high degree of likelihood
that he ordered it. He said it happened under his watch and we could forever judge Saudi Arabia
by that event, or we could also see where Saudi Arabia is going, the direction that it's going,
and recognize that it's a very, very important strategic ally in the region.
I don't think it's fair to continue to judge a country through the Jamal Khashoggi lens forever.
Well, so just continuing this point, one more for just another minute.
Why is it that if Iran is saying it wants that same dealmaker treatment that President Trump was
able to bring to so many of these other conflicts with such success, why not extend that to them?
Why should there be a hard line there as opposed to other places?
Because the deal that Iran is proposing, and again, we don't know similar to what's happening
with the Mar-Laga rate. We don't really know what's going on behind closed doors,
but by all accounts, what the deal would be would simply allow Iran to create a nuclear
weapon in several years. That's not really a smart deal. The deals that Trump was interested in making
were smart deals, long-term deals, deals that made sense for everybody involved. The deal that
Iran seemingly is proposing is something that makes sense for it. And yes, to Robbie's point,
it makes sense for us for a short period of time, and I'll rather than say a short period of time.
It makes sense today, but it won't make sense in several years from now. It certainly won't make
sense when more missiles are flying, whether from Lebanon to Israel, Gaza to Israel,
Yemen to Saudi Arabia, Yemen to the UAE or the UN.
Well, Jason Greenblatt, we so appreciate you joining us. Again, the book is in the path of Abraham,
how Donald Trump made peace in the Middle East, and how to stop Joe Biden from unmaking it.
Thank you so much for joining us today. Thank you for having me.
And we'll be back with more rising right after this.
The US is currently in a friendship recession. That's sad, with men being the focus.
According to a study from the Survey Center on American Life, the percentage of men with
at least six close friends fell by half between 1990 and 2021. Reasons for this phenomenon include
52% of American men ages 18 to 29, still living at home with their parents, working longer hours,
switching jobs more frequently, and individuals are going into a physical office
less than before. According to our next guest, Aubrey Hirsch.
A further study by the Survey Center on American Life noted that men are 79% less likely to receive
emotional support, with studies showing a specific link between suicide and loneliness in men and
a greater fear of intimacy. Here to speak with us on the subject is writer, illustrator,
and author Aubrey Hirsch. Welcome Aubrey. Thanks for having me.
All right. So what do you attribute this to? There's been a lot of conversation about
COVID and lockdowns and the ways that that's changed our society, but it seems like this
phenomenon has predated all of that. Yeah, there's definitely been a line trending downward for
the last like 30 years in terms of, um, men's ability to make and maintain close friendships.
When you hit on a couple of the reasons in your introduction, you know, people are working
longer hours. They're switching jobs more often, um, and going into the office less and all of those
things make it more challenging to create friendships and also to have time for friendships outside of
work. Also, people are living with their parents longer, uh, which offers them emotional support in
in the form of their parents. So they're less likely to go out and find it with their peers.
And also it makes the less room and space to, you know, have parties, have friends over, have just
your own private life, things like that. People are also getting married later, but I also found
in my research, I think a lot of this has to do with the way that we socialize boys into men.
Um, we teach men that their vulnerabilities are a bad thing, that they should hide or
request their emotions. You know, we don't celebrate their connections. We celebrate their
fortitude or, you know, what looks like strength from the outside. Instead of focusing on those
things that, you know, vulnerability is really the most important thing when you're building
connections and building relationships with people. So I think we're also doing men in disservice
when we bring them up and it makes it harder for them to connect when they're older.
But isn't that, uh, I know exactly what you're talking about, but isn't that kind of tendency
weakening a little bit over time? It seemed like I don't know, men of my generation and certainly
the next generation more feel far more, you know, liberated to openly discuss feelings or emotional
connections or all that. Like that really had, I mean, not just men, women, everyone has gotten
more open about talking about their mental well-being, etc. You know, seeking therapy,
all those things, which I would think might foster, um, greater on a, maybe not great, but
greater than previously connections between men. So I'm a little bit surprised that if the trajectory
seems to be away from close male friendships. Yeah, I was surprised too, because that that's
also sort of my impression, but it's possible some of that is just our own experience or the
people that we prefer to surround ourselves with, you know, maybe don't necessarily have these ideas
of traditional masculinity. Oh, also, sorry, there's also some really interesting thinking out
there that men's idea of an ideal woman has shifted really dramatically in the last 30 years.
Like it's no longer everybody's looking for a kind of like quiet, compliant, you know,
homemaker. People are interested in women in leadership positions, you know, they accept women
at colleges and universities, women in power. But the idea of what an ideal man looks like
has not really shifted as much in that time. You know, we still look at men as kind of the same way.
I have some thoughts and feelings. Well, speaking of kind of, um, dating expectations and the
effect that are kind of, um, intimate relationship expectations of on genders are men and women
are affecting this, I'm curious about the effect of online dating, generally speaking, because I
definitely have observed people kind of relying on the ease with which you can access kind of
short-term partners and relationships online. Um, as a substitute for keeping in touch with
friends who are often now further away than they used to, people are very mobile for their careers.
The friends that you met in college might not end up in the same state as you. You don't end up in
the same state as your parents. And there is a way that if you want to be occupied on a weekend,
you can hop on an app and be occupied with someone that is ultimately probably going to be a much
shorter term presence in your life than a friend. What do you make of that?
Yeah, that's really interesting. I didn't look at any research that talked about the effect of
online dating on this phenomenon specifically, but I definitely did look at a fair amount of
research that talked about, uh, women as tending to do things together kind of face to face or like,
you know, interfacing together, talking to each other, even if it's on the phone or via Zoom.
Whereas men tend to do things shoulder to shoulder, you know, sitting together and watching sports
together, going on hikes, you know, doing kind of physical things. So I mean, that would certainly
kind of go along with what you're saying about how if someone's not physically there, it's maybe
more challenging for men to make those connections. But a significant way that men interact with each
other now in a social, uh, manner is video games are a much, much larger point, uh, part of the
male experience than they have been historically video games have gotten really good, really
compelling, very narrative, very statistically, very technologically sophisticated. I play a lot
of video games. I don't play a lot of video games that are, you know, interactive that are online
with other people, but a lot of guys I know do and they're collaborative and social and, you know,
friendly competition usually, not always, but, uh, that would be a dynamic I would point to as a
friendship building thing. But maybe I guess maybe dudes don't, don't, wouldn't, don't, uh,
label their video game buddies as like close friends, even though what they have is kind of a close
friendship. I don't know. Yeah. I mean, that's certainly possible. I think again, that's a great
example of that kind of shoulder to shoulder activity that, you know, men are doing together.
But it doesn't necessarily lend itself to some of the things that popped up in my research, like
talking about a personal problem or offering or receiving emotional support, you know,
telling a friend that you love them. I don't know. I mean, I don't know. You would have to tell me,
but how much is happening during the video game play about it. Love you, man. I love you,
pwned. It is, it is difficult to maintain relationships, I think, for everyone. And you point to the
fact that this is a broader trend that's not exclusive to men. And I think that, you know,
there is a kind of an unspoken amount of labor that goes into coordinating times to get together,
scheduling times for phone calls, doing all of that, especially if people get older and families
and kids come into the mix. And I wonder, you know, what, if anything, people have thought about it
in terms of trying to improve upon this issue, if we do think it's an issue that's, um, leading to,
you know, suicidal deviation and unhappiness more broadly, what's there to be done?
Yeah. Well, you know, the sort of secret sauce to making lasting friendships is vulnerability.
So it's kind of being able to get in touch with yourself to question what you've been told is
important, you know, to question what values you've been told are important for you to have. And then
think about which ones are serving you and which ones aren't. And if there's things that are keeping
you from building these friendships, because you feel like you need to, you know, stoic or show
emotional fortitude, you can make a choice to get rid of that. You can just remove that ideal
from your brain. And instead you can choose to be vulnerable and make connections, you know,
reach out to your friends, make it a priority in your life. Um, you know, all of those things are
important. Mm. Robert, do you think that that's, that's what's coming between to the sense that
there's any issue and keeping friends over the years? Do you think it's, it's your lack of
vulnerability among men? That's the issue. I mean, it's, I guess my experience is just very
different. I mean, I live in a city. I live in a liberal city. I do actually go to the most of my
friends are I'm very close with my coworkers at both of my offices. I'm married. So my wife and
I have a lot of couple friends. So I guess I'm just not in the life situation that this increasing
pool of young men find themselves. Like I, if you have six friends, name them right now.
I don't know if they picked up. No, I'm in a group thread of
guys who I, but I guess we don't, do we talk about emotionally vulnerable stuff?
This is getting very personal. I have a healthy number of friends, but again, I, I go into the
office. I'm in a city. I see people a lot. If you just live at home, if you're not married or in a
long-term relationship, if you live with your parents, if you're not going out because of the
pandemic, sure, I could see how, how you find yourself in a situation where you have, where you
would describe yourself as having few close male friends, which is a, which is a bad thing.
Yeah. And I do think not to gender stereotype, but I have some executive functioning issues where I
find it to be very stressful, the administration of getting people together. And, you know, there
are studies that show that men tend to do less of that kind of administrative social work,
whether it's, you know, housework or making doctors appointments for kids and things like that.
And I do wonder if the bar, if the bar for men, a threshold for men of engaging in those kind of
activities that are required to maintain relationships is so much higher. If that's just the first thing
that's going to fall on the wayside when you get overwhelmed, which again, I think is very
understandable, but might be about kind of the difficulty of getting together and finding time
and increasingly packed lives more than kind of the emotional failures of the less fair.
Do men have more, more feme? I probably not, right? More female friends? That's why they have fewer
male friends. I mean, it's, I, again, in my situation, right, we have a lot of couple friends, a lot of
our social activities, our mixed gender social activities. Yeah, the women are, the women are
doing some planning, sounds like. Yeah, and men who have female friends were more likely to
have received emotional support from a friend in the last week and also more likely to have had
a friend tell them that they love them. Then men who have only male friends. Well, look, you've
given us a lot to talk about and think about Aubrey. I'm sure we're going to keep this conversation
going after this segment wrap. So we appreciate you spending this time with us today. I want to
see the group chat. No, you do not. All right, we'll have more rising after that. We went to
Brianna. We'll have more rising right after this.
The state of Rhode Island is tackling the rent crisis through a new $10 million private program
that will use COVID-19 stimulus money to build mixed income public housing. As reported by Ricardo
Gomez and the lever, the pilot program is just one part of the state's Create Homes Act,
which would use $300 million of American Rescue Plan Act funds to create a new state housing
department, realigning public spending with the public good. Joining us now to expand on that is
fellow at the lever Ricardo Gomez. Welcome to rising. Hi, thank you for having me.
Ricardo, help us understand what the experience of the housing crisis is right now. More broadly,
specifically in Rhode Island. What are renters up against?
Well, the situation in Rhode Island is much like many places. Rents are on the rise and
there's not a whole lot of relief. This is for a number of reasons, which is
A, that any new housing units that are being built are being built at market rate. Landlords are
increasing prices without consultation. Responses, there's been a rise in tenant rights organizing,
tenant unionization, but at the same time, landlords in Rhode Island have also been forming
basically lobbying groups to combat those efforts. Yeah, this is, I don't know, I think I would say
that this is a very similar experience that people are facing in a lot of different places.
All right, well, how does creating a new housing department help alleviate this problem?
Well, so over the last couple of decades, the primary program for building affordable housing
has been the low income housing tax credit program, which largely is private developers
tax tax credits. So it incentivizes housing developers who are seeking profits to build
housing. What the public developer program would do is equip the state to take over land planning,
land acquisition, and the actual building of housing units. This would mean that the way that
we're organizing collectively to build housing is not motivated by profits or by private developers
seeking to get public resources. But instead, it's for the goal of simply creating housing. So
creating this public developer program, getting it off the ground through the pilot program
is a step of creating like one coordinated system of creating housing for the public that
isn't motivated or driven by profits, but for addressing a very basic need, which is the need
for housing. Well, can you help me understand why it is the federal housing program, the LIHC,
the low income housing tax credit program is so susceptible to these private developer interests,
but the state level program won't be? Yeah, well, I would say with the LIHTCs, there's a
fundamental misalignment of public spending and public good. I mentioned that in my piece.
Basically, there's very little oversight of these actors. The housing that they do build,
which is supposed to be affordable, has expires like over 30 years. Any affordable housing that
they build will basically convert back into market housing. The difference is that under a public
developer model, the housing won't have expirability. Affordability will be,
you know, there will be more oversight about what is actually considered affordable would be geared
towards workforce housing. By definition, like the LIHC program is set out to incentivize people
who are looking for profits, right? The public developer program is sort of made more democratic
by allowing a public entity, which, you know, is subject to the interests of people to oversee
the building of the housing, rather than letting private actors regulate things and drive things.
It seems kind of wild that this federal program would have these obvious flaws in it. If expirability
is the issue, why is that the case? If there are not the right incentives and conditions put on
building that are actually motivating more low-income housing to be built as opposed to the for-profit
higher income or profitable housing, why is that not built in the federal program? You know, is it
lobbying interest? Is it, you know, what has there not been a lot of public scrutiny about the
LIHC model? Yeah, maybe. I mean, definitely public scrutiny, but also there are a lot of
money. There are a lot of people getting a lot of money from this program. You know, there were
investigations done recently that saw that the program is rife with corruption. People take money
that is supposedly going to be going to developing housing and will spend it on on dinners with
clients. The whole program, when you have a program that is oriented around letting private
actors who are seeking profits determine something as basic as housing, like there are just some
fundamental problems there. And, you know, this goes back to in the 30s and 40s when the federal
government was initially expanding things like the like HUD building public housing
that shifted in the 70s and the neoliberal period to giving more control over housing to
these private actors building the housing. So, I don't know, that shift is really important.
The lack of oversight is really important, but also just like the fundamental alignment of
interest, which is they're seeking profits, not housing. I don't know that that. I don't know
about the situation in Rhode Island specifically, but in other places where there is not enough
housing, a large or affordable housing, a large contributor to that problem is just that there's
not enough housing in general, often because of zoning, local actors who oppose new development,
regardless of, you know, what if it's going to be affordable or not. An expansion of the housing
supply would drive down prices even if the new developments aren't specifically designated for
affordable housing. Sometimes some aspect of them are affordable. Is there any, is there,
Rhode Island is a very small set at the local level, are there, are there, you know, zoning actors
and historical preservation boards, that kind of thing standing in the way of having more housing?
Well, something to respond to this, I think an important part of breaking down the public developer
model is that it would, it would let the state or at the municipal level to sort of coordinate
the zoning laws that you're talking about. There are a lot of, like the developers have a lot of
interest in making sure that those zoning laws aren't designated to actually building
affordable housing. In Rhode Island in particular, as people have been, have tenants have been
organizing against rents, bikes, against evictions, as I was saying earlier, different groups from
mom and pop landlords to bigger developers also coordinate their lobbying interests to sort of
prevent the changing of these zoning laws. I guess I would focus on talking about how the
public developer program allows all of these sorts of rules to be brought under the purview of one
public entity. So under the public developer, there would be tools for the state to review,
for example, zoning and save vacancies of properties and either require places to
provide a plan for the usage of this land or to put the land up for sale to the state of Rhode
Island. So there's a sort of mechanism there or tools to sort of address this question that
you're bringing up about zoning or about where affordable housing can be built. And it sort of
all folded in into what the public developer program would do, which is to sort of efficiently
build housing and taking control or at least having more say in the matter of zoning is a big
step to that. In addition, having a public developer, having the government step in would mean that
the government wouldn't necessarily be held hostage to public developers who are refraining from
investing and building housing. They can step in and sort of drive that process.
I'm seeing the claim that Rhode Island has produced the least new housing supply per capita of any
state in the country. Seems like a substantial part of the problem. Ricardo Gomez, thank you so
much for joining us. Thank you. We'll have more rising right after this.
Well, Chicago billionaire gave the largest known political donation to a political advocacy group
in history worth $1.6 billion. According to new reporting from the lever, 90 year old Barr
A. Side gave the massive sum to a nonprofit run by Leonard Leo, who co-chairs the conservative legal
group, the Federalist Society. Andrew Perez joins us now to discuss further. Andrew, welcome to rising.
Thank you. Thanks for having me. So Leonard Leo gave this don't. Leonard Leo's group actually put
out a release, I think is the case of announcing this donation. We're not just relying on reports.
This is publicly. We know that the sum is $1.6 billion. It's not straight to FedSock. It's to
another group that Leo started, right? Yeah, yeah. So the $1.6 billion is reflected in the first
tax return released by this new group from Leonard Leo called the Marble Freedom Trust. We've been
working on this story, the lever team in ProPublica for quite a while, looking at some documents that
we were given showing the transaction detailing how this money went from this Chicago billionaire
Berry Side to the Marble Freedom Trust and how they sort of gamed the tax code to maximize the
the most amount of money here. So Berry Side actually donated his entire company, this company
called Triplet, this electronics and surge protector manufacturer. He donated the entire company,
